text: A serene landscape, mist collecting as the red ball of a dips behind the mountains. In the middle of a field stands a bare-chested man facing sunset. He is HARRIS, forty-ish, greying but handsome, an very fit. His hands are outstretched as if embracing an invisible entity. He seems filled with some sort of transcendental power. Now, an air of fulfillment and reso settles over him. He turns and walks away from us. CAMERA ADJUSTS and reveals--

Once the home of Victorian Gentry, a few seasons of amate repair work have not compensated for decades of neglect. now as Harris walks towards it, the fading daylight and l shadows turn it into a fantasy castle. MUSIC ECHOES faint from within; it's "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida" by Iron Butterfly. the music didn't place the era for us, the battered VW MINIBUS parked outside the house does; it's covered with flower paintings, slogans, and the ubiquitous peace sign. As Harris approaches the house, a dozen or so YOUNG PEOPL rush to greet him and embrace him. Extending his arms out enclose them all, he goes inside.

This was probably a stately parlor in its day. There is a funky assembly of odd handmade furniture. There are musli curtains on the windows, crude paintings, and quilts cove ripped chairs and couches. Despite the squalor, there is neatness to the place. Now, the CAMERA begins to ROAM through the room and down the hallways lined with fading wallpaper.
(various)
--where did she go...? ... was here a moment ago... Cynthia, come on, honey, we need you... Cynthia, come out, come out wherever you are... the sun's going down, we're losing the moment...!

Hey, mellow out, we got ten minutes, I like, checked the almanac, okay...? Ready or not, here we come... All these comments are made in relaxed and good natured tones. Finally the CAMERA PANS OVER to a little storage alcove beneath the servant's stairway. A HAND reaches in opens the door, and inside we SEE cartons, antique toys.. and then CYNTHIA, a pretty 13 year old girl who wears fun clothing and a haunted, nervous expression.

...There you are, you naughty girl! You almost made us lose the sunset... Come on, honey, time's wasting... She shrinks back from the HANDS that are pulling her up a out, but they prevail, and she's up and on unsteady feet. The CAMERA stays with her as she's led back down the hall
(faintly)
No, please... I... I really don't want to do this... Can't I just wait for you..? I--I'm not sure about this-- A SET OF HANDS moves in, separates Cynthia from the other
Revealing VICTOR, a handsome youth a few years older than Cynthia.

Easy, Cyn, easy. You don't want to do this, that's okay... right, Harris? The VOICES stop as everyone awaits an answer. CAMERA PANS across the common room, to the end we haven't seen yet. In the center of the room is a big cistern or font. As we watch, Harris has just DUNKED someone in it. The person steps out, laughing, sloshing in amber liquid. Standing around are other people, some already dripping wet, other awaiting their turns. Some are clothed and wet, others in varying degrees of undress. It all seems slightly off, slightly eerie, despite their smiles and cheer. Harris splashes himself with the amber liquid from the tub, push his hair back.
No, Victor, it's not okay. Here at Unity House, some things have to be done... (slight smile)
...in Unity. This is one of them. He WADES CLOSER to the CAMERA, within reach of Cynthia, Victor and the others. Smiles again. It's the kind of a smile that inspires trust.
Cynthia, do you trust me? She nods immediately.

And have I ever lied to you? She shakes her head. He GESTURES. The people around Cynth begin to GET INTO the tub. Some remove their clothing; others get in clothes and all. Toddlers and infants are h by their parents and playfully splashed.

Then I say to you now... to all of you now... that this will be the Ultimate Joining... of man and woman... parent and child... humanity and Godhead. He looks at Victor, who reluctantly lets Cynthia's hand g gets in. Now only Cynthia remains.
Cynthia. Come. There is no shame in this. No crime. No sin. Just the final break with the old world... As night falls, we start a new day... a day of Unity. (a command, but warm)
Come to me... my lovechild.

His last words melt her remaining resistance. Moving like sleepwalker, she steps into the tub, wades forward. Then stops, looks down at the fluid lapping at her jeans... ru her hand through it. Her eyes widen.
The sun almost gone now, red light reflecting on the gabl windows. Even the battered VW van looks good in this setting. It's beautiful.
No!   No... HARRIS' VOICE

Cynthia, come back! We can't do it without you... We must have unity, my lovechild... Unity, now and through eternity... Cynthia, you cannot run... You belong to us forever--! Pause. The faint SOUNDS of SPLASHING and then FOOTSTEPS skittering on tired wooden floors... and then--

WINDOWS blow out. Splintered BEAMS propeller through the air. The VW camper on the lawn ROCKS with the shock wave. Then a SECOND EXPLOSION blows the Victorian cupolas and widow's walk off the roof. From somewhere in the distance HEAR SIRENS...
FIRE is CONSUMING what's left of the building. Rescue workers and firefighters are running back and forth.

A plainclothes detective, he NODS to some uniforms, steps around some debris to move closer to the scene. He puts h collar up against the SPRAY which leaks from firehose connections. Seeing one of his men, he SHOUTS over the di WASSERMAN
What have we got? POLICEMAN
Twenty-four bodies, Inspector. Maybe more.
As he says this, both men watch as firefighters carry out SCORCHED AND BLACKENED CORPSE that looks like a 3,000 yea old mummy.
It's set down on the ground beside other blackened bodies partially covered by tarps. As the body is set down it CRUNCHES, and a piece BREAKS OFF.
Wasserman blanches, wipes his mouth.
Cause of fire?
Some kind of explosion... gas main, methane, too soon to tell. God only knows.
Let's hope He doesn't keep it to Himself.
We got one! We got a survivor! Get a stretcher and oxygen over here, STAT!
Wasserman and the cop run up the slope with the others.

Medics run around the parked VW, which drips water and chemical foam. Rescue workers move a FALLEN BEAM and pull soot-blackened form out of a hole. As the CAMERA PUSHES closer, we see that it is Cynthia. Her clothes are torn a singed, and she is unconscious, but as they work on her w see that she is largely unharmed.

(busy, frantic) Make room, make room! Get that airway in! I got a pulse, whoa, it's faint... Talk about lucky, she musta fallen in the basement... First and second degree burns... Come on people, move your asses!

Wasserman tries to keep up as they carry her on a stretch towards an ambulance, put her inside. It ROARS AWAY, SIRE WAILING. MUSIC COMES UP AND OVER-- it's MAGIC CARPET RIDE Steppenwolf. NEWSCASTER'S VOICE (filtered)

--Authorities continue to investigate yesterday's mysterious explosion and fire at Unity House, the controversial New Age commune headed by self-styled Guru Adrian Harris. 32 people died in the blaze. Thirteen year old Cynthia Weston, the fire's only survivor, remains in guarded but stable condition at County General. In national news, newspaper heiress Patricia Hearst was abducted from her Bay area apartment shortly before dawn today... A communique from the so-called "Symbionese Liberation Army" demanded that...
The doors CRASH ASIDE as Cynthia is rushed in on a gurney The CEILING LIGHTS flicker past us as they move her into emergency room. VOICES

Blood pressure 90 over 30, we're losing her... Where's that cart? CLEAR! CLEAR! Okay, it's climbing... Watch the EEG... Brain activity, shit, damn low... We begin a SERIES OF DISSOLVES, including: A) WASSERMAN, who appears first in his clothes from the fire, then two other wardrobe changes; B) HOSPITAL PERSONNEL, at first the harried and rushed emergency staff, and then the more blase regular doctors and nurses; C) VARIOUS MEDICAL EQUIPMENT, as a series of DIAGNOSTIC TESTS are run on Cynthia--

D) CYNTHIA, first in her fire-scorched clothing, then as it is cut away, and then in several HOSPITAL GOWNS, first white, then green, then blue... E) A SERIES OF HOSPITAL ROOMS AND LABS; P) HOSPITAL CHARTS AND FILES, with ever-changing DATES;

(over this) No sign of physical damage but neurological functions still depressed... Sorry, Inspector, no changes... Patient comatose after 14 days... Brain scan shows minor irregularities; pupil function within normal range... Still no sign of consciousness... Still comatose after 21 days ... Sorry, Inspector, we'll call you if there's any progress... Still comatose after 42 days... Patient moved out of intensive care....

As the MONTAGE CONTINUES, TITLES BEGIN. Now we HEAR VARIO NEWS BROADCASTS which come UP AND OVER, fading IN AND OUT with the medical VOICES. (If desired, TV NEWSCASTS might seen as well on a hospital room's set.)

(filtered, in and out, intermittently audible) ...The mother of Martin Luther King Junior was assassinated today while she played the organ in her son's church... interrupt to bring this bulletin... Richard Milhous Nixon has resigned as President of the United States... As the Marine guards hold back the crowds, the last helicopters took off from the roof of the Embassy in Saigon... Bicentennial festivities begin today in Philadelphia...
We SEE Cynthia in her bad, always in the same near-fetal position. The only changes are the occasionally different hues of her blankets and the varying length of her hair.

--leak at the Three Mile Island facility... 73 Americans remain hostage in the Teheran Embassy... Ronald Reagan has been elected 40th President... renewed fighting in the Middle East... assailant shot John Lennon at point blank range... President Reagan has been shot! He is in guarded condition at... The Pope has been shot! He was rushed by ambulance to... President Anwar Sadat has been assassinated...
We SEE several SHOTS of this man, first as a white-coated RESIDENT in his late 30's, walking past Cynthia's hospita doorway, and then stopping, curious, and looking in on he and then in--
as (with changing wardrobe and increasing status) he chec in on the girl's unaltered condition as months and years continue to click by:

...the Korean airliner was shot down by a Soviet jet, killing all 269 people aboard... invasion of the island Nation of Grenada... Prime Minister Indira Ghandi was assassinated by members of her own bodyguard... the PLO hijackers shot the wheelchair-bound American and threw his body overboard... Space Shuttle Challenger exploded moments after launch... renewed fighting today in the Middle East... President Corazon Aquino asked the soldiers to lay down their arms... Senator Gary Hart withdrew from the race... Fawn Hall... Lieutenant Colonel Oliver North... Contrascam Investigation... PTL scandal... munitions train severed the lag of a protester at the... renewed fighting in the Middle East...
The HEAD NURSE looks up, smiles at a YOUNG FLOOR NURSE as walks past. From somewhere we HEAR a Springsteen song on radio. HEAD NURSE
Debbie. What happened to your windsurfing lesson? YOUNG NURSE
No wind. I changed shifts with Nancy. (picking up charts)
Well... time to weed the vegetable patch. We FOLLOW the young nurse as she goes into--

Bored, the nurse goes to the foot of the bad, checks the chart there. She moves past MONITORING EQUIPMENT which sh only subtle movement. As she begins to take Cynthia's blo pressure, CAMERA CONTINUES ON INTO THE BED and we see Cynthia, She is now a fully grown young woman in her late 20's. is curled up in a fetal ball.

finishes her work and then gathers some bottles from the table. She goes to the door and then REACTS to a SOUND. She looks around, puzzled. Meanwhile, we SEE (and she DOESN'T) that there is INCREASED ACTIVITY on the monitors CYNTHIA (faint, weak)
No... no... it's wrong... someone... please help... YOUNG NURSE

Holy shit... Stunned, the nurse DROPS the bottles with a CRASH. Recovering her composure, she darts back to the bed, watc flabbergasted as Cynthia continues to STIR, her arms weak battling half-realized fears.
The young nurse hits an ALARM, grabs Cynthia's arms to prevent her from pitching out of the bed, and then DOCTOR and NURSES are scrambling all over the room, and as the D RISES we
FLASHBULBS pop and the HOSPITAL SPOKESMAN grins clumsily, famous for fifteen minutes. There's eight or nine reporters here, all of them wishing they were on bigger stories.
(in mid speech) Twelve years, two months...   nine days.
Is that like a world record for a coma or something?
Actually, no. The longest one on record is 37 years.
The first reporter closes a notebook, leaves.
Does she remember anything about the fire at Universe House?

head_text.subj: SHOWING THE BACK OF THE ROOM

text: Lieutenant (nee Inspector) Wasserman is there.    He's gr paunchier, but the raincoat is the same one.
(correcting) Unity House. No, she appears to have no memory of the accident itself or the days leading up to it. It's not uncommon after serious trauma.
What happens to her now? Have her family or friends been notified?

We stopped looking for any family ton years ago.. Right now we"re planning to transfer Cynthia to Dr. S.A. Berrisford's Neuropsychiatric Clinic. It's right here on our grounds, and Dr. Berrisford is familiar with both the neuromuscular problems a patient like this will encounter as well as the inevitable mental readjustment that will be required. Thank you.
The reporters filter out. Wasserman is already gone.
as it is clumsily set down...    another FOOT slides forw
Cynthia is standing inside a set of parallel bars. She's pale, weak looking. A PHYSICAL THERAPIST is at her elbow, egging her on.
Good... Very good... Come on, just a few more steps...
Cynthia blinks, as if just processing the therapist's wor takes some adjustment.
(weary) I... I can't... I have to rest...
Young lady, you've had fifteen years of rest.
CAMERA ADJUSTS to show DR. BERRISFORD. In his 50's, avuncular, he wears half-framed glasses and a sweater ves under his medical coat. Two pieces of tissue paper mark h razor's passage on his neck.
BERRISFORD (CONT'D)
Now walk to the end of that platform, or you won't got any chocolate ice cream. Something about Berrisford's mock-stern tone bores in on Cynthia, gets a reaction. She gropes for an answer. CYNTHIA
(finally) I... I hate chocolate ice cream. BERRISFORD

Then walk to the end of the platform, or I'll shove an entire gallon down your throat. Cynthia's eyes crinkle with confusion. And then, ah, she gets it! A joke, the first one in over a decade. She SMILES, and it's a beautiful smile. Setting her jaw, she makes a renewed effort and reaches the and of the platfor The therapist and Berrisford both move quickly to catch h and set her down in a wheelchair. BERRISFORD

(to the therapist) That'll be all. Berrisford begins wheeling Cynthia along. They leave the therapy room, go down a corridor. (Note: Passage as per location.) As they go by other patients and staff, there' general BUZZ as people whisper about Cynthia. CYNTHIA
(peering at Berrisford) Am I supposed to know you or something? BERRISFORD

I've looked in on you from time to time... but that's hardly an introduction. You've been transferred into my care, Cynthia. I*m Doctor S. A. Berrisford, Consulting Chief of Neuropsychiatry and head of the Berrisford Clinic. CYNTHIA
(fumbling it) C-consulting Cheev-- Chief of--
BERRISFORD
Oh, forget all that.   Just call me what my staff does. CYNTHIA
What's that? BERRISFORD
God. Cynthia LAUGHS. She likes this man's directness, the way doesn't condescend to her.
Berrisford parks her and site down across from her. CYNTHIA
What... what kind of doctor did you say you were? Berrisford notices one of the tissues on his neck.    Sco flicks it away. BERRISFORD
Obviously, I'm not a surgeon. (as she laughs)
I'm a psychiatrist. CYNTHIA (puzzled)
Why do I need a psychiatrist?

Cynthia, you've been out of touch with reality for over ten years. Your recovery goes beyond your muscle tone... You have to ease into life... into interacting with other people again. Into a world that's changed so much that sometimes I get confused by it. (taking out an appointment book)
Now, my assistant Dr. Goldman has a group therapy session every day... I'm putting you down for it, starting tomorrow...
(unsure) Group therapy? But--
Dr. Berrisford?
Revealing Wasserman.    He shows his badge to the doctor.
I'm Lieutenant Wasserman. I left a message with your secretary...?
(rising, meeting him halfway) And I left one with your desk sergeant. (a hard whisper) I told you this would have to wait. You shouldn't even be here--
She can't help but listen as they continue in lowered ton
I've waited fifteen years. That's long enough. Now I want to speak with Miss Weston.
Miss Weston is still recovering and is in no condition for a prolonged interrogation.
(tight smile) Then don't prolong it. I'll be brief with her, I'll be gentle with her--
I'll let you know when she's ready--
E--excuse me...
They turn and look at her. CYNTHIA (CONT'D)
Doctor Berrisford, what's this all about...? This man wants to talk to me...? Berrisford starts to answer, but Wasserman rushes in. WASSERMAN (quietly, slowly, as if to a child)
That's right, Miss Weston. I just have a few easy, simple questions. (patient, phony smile)
About you... and about Unity House. Cynthia looks at him strangely, turns to Berrisford. CYNTHIA (sotto)
Why is he talking like that? Is he one of your patients? Wasserman burns.   Berrisford LAUGHS. BERRISFORD

Lieutenant Wasserman is a police officer. And the word "patience" isn't part of his vocabulary. Wasserman scowls, not enjoying being the butt of a joke. resumes his normal tons, which is far from diplomatic. WASSERMAN
Miss Weston. What's the last thing you remember before... CYNTHIA
--Before the accident?   Nothing. WASSERMAN
Then how do you know it was an accident? BERRISFORD
Lieutenant!
CYNTHIA
I remember... a beautiful sunset. Harris, smiling at me... WASSERMAN
(writing) Harris, he was the leader? Cynthia's eyes are far away.    The memories come back... words are slow, but vivid. CYNTHIA

Leader, founder... chief cook and bottlewasher... (smiling) Executive in charge of Dreaming. We were all together... all working to make a now world... That last night, there was a... (brow furrowing) Gathering... a... a sort of... baptism... And then... She winces, rubs her eyes. CYNTHIA (CONT'D)
I'm sorry, that's all I can see. WASSERMAN
Miss Weston. This "Unity House"... was it a cult? CYNTHIA
I'm sorry.     I don't understand the question. BERRISFORD

A "cult," Cynthia. A syndrome of society you have been fortunate enough to miss. They're popular with impressionable people, the penny press... (pause) ...and lazy policemen who like to blame them for crimes they can't solve. Wasserman closes his notebook, gives Berrisford a cold st WASSERMAN
I was there that night, Doctor. I watched them stack those bodies... (MORE)
men, women, children. They looked like 2,000 year old mummies. They broke apart like 2,000 year old mummies. Cynthia gasps. WASSERMAN (CONT'D)
If it was an accident... fine. If it wasn't... the person responsible could still be out there. (pause)
And he's probably as interested in Miss Weston's memory as I am. He turns, nods to Cynthia. WASSERMAN (CONT'D)
Feel better. He goes out.   Cynthia's breath comes in short gasps.   F she calms. CYNTHIA
I don't like that man. BERRISFORD
That makes two of us. He sits beside her again. BERRISFORD (CONT'D)
But as long as you're here... (smiling)
I can keep him away. CAMERA TIGHTENS on Cynthia as she considers this...

The room is cheery, commands a view of the city. A VIDEO CAMERA sits unobtrusively in one corner. Six people sit i chairs in various stages of interest and/or boredom. They are MIRIAM, an attractive woman in her forties, who chain-smokes designer cigarettes; CONNIE, smiling, chipper;

ED, overweight, friendly; LANA, pale, worried looking; and GILDA, tiny, frightened, withdrawn. She sits with fee pulled up on her chair, arms wrapped around her knees. CAMERA ADJUSTS to show Cynthia driving her electric wheelchair into the room and into a place in the circle. RALPH stands. Long-haired, with the staccato delivery of stand-up comic, he smiles. RALPH

Well, now that we're all here, we can begin. Cynthia, I'm Dr. Goldman, and I'd like to welcome you to our little group. I don't know how much my colleague Dr. Berrisford has told you about my methods. I have my detractors... but I have my successes, too! We're going to get you out of your depression... We're going to got you out of your neurosises... We're going to got you out of that hideous hospital robe and into a flimsy revealing negligee--one with the little holes here? I can see us now on a desert island... You, me, a portable waterbed-- As Cynthia's eyes widen, DR. ALAN GOLDMAN comes into the room, sighs with weary familiarity at Ralph's antics. (Actually, Alan doesn't look much more like a doctor than Ralph.) ALAN
Ralph, sit down and cut out the shit, okay? RALPH
Dr. Goldman, I was on the verge of a major breakthrough, and you blew it! ALAN
Ralph? (when he sits) Cynthia. I'm Doctor Goldman--at least, last time I checked... (MORE)
and I doubt if my welcome can equal Ralph's, but I'll try. This is the Borderline Personality Group. And you are now a card-carrying member. CYNTHIA
What's a borderline personality? MIRIAM
Don't ask him. He's making this up as he goes along. ALAN

A borderline personality is one that can't be accurately placed on the Neurosis-Psychosis arc. As a personality syndrome it encompasses identity crises, chemical addictions, emotionalism, anxiety- RALPH
(standing, SCREAMING like Sam Kinison) You forgot VIOLENT MOOD SWINGS! He sits, smiles sweetly. CONNIE
He also forgot suicidal tendencies. But, as one whose previous reincarnations stretch back to Ancient Atlantis, well, suicide is meaningless anyway. ED
And don't forgot binge eating. (pause) Gourmet binge eating. MIRIAM
(sweetly, to Cynthia) I told you he was making this up. ALAN
If everyone is finished-- LANA
(breaking in) They're not finished, Dr. Goldman, they won't be finished until they have her feeling as miserable and pathetic and confused as they are.
CYNTHIA
I am confused-- LANA
See? (to the group) I hope you're all happy-- CYNTHIA
Dr. Goldman, I... I don't really know what I'm doing here. I mean... I don't think I meet your description of a Borderline Personality-- RALPH
Give yourself some time, Cynthia. We'll help you work on it. CYNTHIA
--and I don't really know what I'm doing here. ALAN
Didn't Dr. Berrisford explain? CYNTHIA
He said he thought that this would help me... fit into the 80's. Miriam CRACKS UP. MIRIAM
Honey, you want to fit into the 80's, you're already two divorces, one condo and a yeast infection behind. Why don't you just catch up with the 70's and move to Cleveland? ALAN
If I can offer a more practical suggestion... Why don't you talk, Cynthia? CYNTHIA
Talk...? ALAN
About something close to you.
MIRIAM
Stop beating around the fucking bush, Goldman! Just come out and ask her! LANA
(to Miriam) Do you have to be so crude? MIRIAM

Come on, Cynthia. Dish out the dirt. Tell us all about Unity House. (gesturing a marquee) The last gasp of the Age of Aquarius. Building a better world through... what? Chemistry? Good vibrations? Tie-dying your undies? CYNTHIA
I'm sorry to disappoint you. I don't have those kinds of stories. RALPH
Back off, Miriam. Cynthia, just tell us about the orgies. CYNTHIA
Ralph, I'm going to bore you. She thinks for a minute, starts to speak. She's hesitant first, and then the old memories come forward. She's sincere, earnest... captivating. CYNTHIA (CONT'D)

What we felt... what we believed... was that if people could become selfless enough, if they could free themselves from their egos, they would experience a... togetherness. A... oneness. A Unity. That's where the name came from. We had a dream about a perfect society based on trust. On love. On totally committed togetherness. We weren't trying to change the whole world. We were just trying to change each other. Pause.   Everyone is affected by her sincerity.
(acting out)
Bullshit.
No.
AS everyone turns, astonished. Gilda gets out of her chai slowly walks towards Cynthia. Takes her hand. And smiles.
It's beautiful. It didn't matter if it worked. All that mattered was... you tried.
(touched) Exactly!
WIDEN from a TV SCREEN which shown the above moment.   As group session CONTINUES UNDER, CAMERA PANS to reveal Berrisford and Alan watching the tape.
Gilda hasn't said three words in three weeks. And now, Cynthia comes in with this love, peace and Woodstock routine and... presto. Am I missing something, or what?
She's espousing a total belief system. A kind of holistic healing matrix not unlike the dynamic energy shift model. Isn't that interesting? They're adopting it, embracing it.
Too bad we can't follow through on this.
Why not?
Dr. Berrisford, the people in this group... some of them are deeply disturbed. Cynthia doesn't belong with them-- an experiment for one session, fine, but in the long run--

Alan. We've opened primary channels of communication. You've opened them, Alan. Let's not rush to throw away our progress. Neuroses are hardly contagious. A few weeks in the group won't hurt Cynthia. With luck, she'll overcome her memory trauma. That would mean progress... not to Mention getting Lieutenant Wasserman off my back. In the meantime...
He stands, puts his hand on the younger man's shoulder.
She seems to like you. See if you can get her to open up, and let's press on. (pause) With a united front?
A united front.   Sure.
Satisfied, Berrisford smiles, goes out the door.     Alan and looks at Cynthia's image on the screen.

Patients in different stages of fitness use the equipment some with supervision, others on their own. HETTIE, Berrisford's chief nurse--a Selma Diamond type--comes in a tray of medication in paper cups. She works her way ove to where
is doing log lifts on a bench. She's in a leotard and leg warmers, and there's real color in her face for the first time.
HETTIE
Drop down to first gear, honey. It's Miller time. She fumbles on her tray for the cup marked "Weston," hand the pills to Cynthia along with a cup of juice. CYNTHIA
What are these? Vitamins? HETTIE
Beauty secrets from the orient. Look what they've done for me. Cynthia laughs, takes the pills. Hettie moves over to Ral who's just finished doing bench presses. HETTIE
Ralph, you in a cooperative mood, or do I have to tie you up again? RALPH
Promises, promises. He takes the pills she gives him, smiles.      She just l him, taps his mouth. HETTIE
Open. Of course the pills are still under his tongue. Hettie gi him a shot in the solar plexus and he GULPS. Hettie hands him the juice. HETTIE (CONT'D)
Next time I hit lower. She moves on to other patients.     Ralph moves over to C RALPH
She's crazy about me. (watching Cynthia's workout)
You're coming along. A regular Rocky. CYNTHIA
Rocky?   The flying squirrel? RALPH
Rocky the fighting Stallone. (on her blank look) (MORE)
I keep forgetting you just left the Twilight Zone. Hey, why don't you come up to my room, and I'll bring you up to date. I've got a VHS VCR, a CD, and MTV. CYNTHIA
You're making this up...      aren't you? He just grins. She slips down to the floor, does some stretching exercises. CYNTHIA (CONT'D)
Sounds like a complicated world. How do you handle it? RALPH
Well, whenever it gets to be too much, I just let all of the negative stuff out of my body. CYNTHIA
You mean with meditation, yoga, what? RALPH

Nah. I just make a little hole and let it all escape. He pulls open his shirt. On his chest and arms are dozens scars in neat little rows. Cynthia swallows, stunned.      Nonplussed, Ralph buttons up. RALPH (CONT'D)
Uh-uh, here comes the assistant Ayatollah. See ya. As Ralph exits, Cynthia looks around, puzzled. CYNTHIA
"Ay-a-toll-ah..?" Then she sees Alan. ALAN
Buy you some lunch? CYNTHIA
Sure.
He starts to help her up.   She pushes him off gets up wi theatrical hop. ALAN
I'm impressed. They walk out of the therapy room. CYNTHIA
Impressed enough to call me a cab? ALAN
I'm not sure I follow you. CYNTHIA
I've been talking to Ralph. He told me about his... personal therapy program. (as Alan winces)
And I've been watching the others... Dr. Goldman, they belong here. I don't.
They pass Lana and Miriam who are swallowing medication f Hettie's tray. The two women patients wave at Cynthia, wh smiles. ALAN (as they walk)
Please, call me Alan. Doctor Goldman is my father... (thinking)
...and my grandfather. I think my first baby toy was a stethoscope-- CYNTHIA
You're changing the subject... (trying it out)
--Alan. I'm feeling stronger. I'm getting used to things like VC esses and MCDs. I want to leave. ALAN (carefully)
Your parents died when you were a child. We haven't been able to locate any relatives. He stops at the elevator doors, hits the button.
Where would you go?
I guess I'd just look up some of the old hands from Unity House... crash with them for a while... (thinking) ...do people still say "crash"--?
Cynthia... (gently) There aren't any old hands left. The fire that injured you...? It took everyone also with it. They're all gone.
Cynthia reacts as if struck...    has to loan against the to catch her breath.
I knew there were deaths...   but... everybody?

I'm afraid so. Look, Cynthia... I'm not saying this to upset you, but the sooner you realize that that whole phase of your life is over, and move on, the better off you're going to be. Why don't you bring this into the open... talk about it in group? Oh, here's our ride.
Saying this, he turns as an elevator OPENS.      It's pre crowded. He holds the door for her.
(confused) Talk about it...?
Seeing he's waiting, she straightens, moves into the elevator.
Could somebody hit one?   Thanks.
CYNTHIA

(to him) "Talk about it in group." Is that the answer to everything around here? The doors CLOSE. Everyone huddles in the compact space silently, politely. The elevator heaves into movement. HUMS as it whisks down the shaft. The overhead fluorescent light in the car is weak.    It flickers off and on momentarily. ALAN
Nobody ever said it would be easy. And it works for a lot of people. CYNTHIA
(gently) It's not working for Ralph... or his chest. (pleading tone) Can't you at least transfer me... get me in a group of people with problems a little more like mine-- ALAN

Cynthia, we don't have a lot of patients who've been in a coma for over a decade! The light gets weaker. Finally it just goes out.     Ther general SIGH of annoyance from the passengers. The light FLICKERS on every few seconds giving off the ef of a strobe light. A PASSENGER
You'd think with what they charge here they could pay their electric bills LAUGHTER. CYNTHIA
Relax. They're probably giving shock therapy. (for Alan's benefit) "It works for most people". More LAUGHTER. Then Cynthia is RIVETED by the sight of something across the elevator.
In the LIGHT of the next strobe like FLASH, we see HARRIS He is staring at Cynthia.

Staggered, disbelievingly, she moves behind Alan, looks o to the far corner again. Another FLASH. Harris is gone. Suddenly the ELEVATOR JERK TO A HALT, but the doors DON'T OPEN. Passengers GROAN, annoyed.
Oh, great--

The emergency BELL starts sounding. Cynthia, still confus gets shoved against the back wall as the passengers busy themselves pushing buttons. Cynthia bumps into the man next to her.        She looks FLASH.   It is Harris. FLASH. Harris reaches out to Cynthia. She CRIES OUT, jerk away, slamming into Alan, falling to the floor.
Jesus, lady, relax! We're on the ground floor--
Let me out! Let me out--!
FLASH. Cynthia is on the floor. She raises her head. Someone is on the floor right across from her. FLASH.   It's Harris.    His face is burned and skeletal. GRINS.
Unity, Cynthia...   Now and forever!
He has no eyelids or lips. Cynthia SCREAMS, struggles to feet, knocking over another passenger. Now it's chaos in here.
Let me out, let me out!   Alan, help, help--!
HARRIS
Cynthia, you cannot run...      You belong to us Forever--!
Struggles across the crowded elevator, catches her in his arms.
Cynthia..? The elevator doors suddenly OPEN.

Cynthia literally TUMBLES out of the elevator, staggers a the wall, holding herself up. Alan runs out to aid her. T passengers get off the elevator, looking at her oddly. A CUSTODIAN runs up and turns off the alarm. ALAN
Cynthia, what happened--?
It's him!     It's him!   He's alive-- ALAN
Who's alive? CYNTHIA (pointing)
He's alive! Right over-- She stops. The elevator is open and empty. The passengers watch her, some concerned, some voyeuristic. Now they dri away. CYNTHIA (CONT'D) (weakly)
--there... Alan just stares at her.
Berrisford sits, listens intently to Alan.
ALAN
--hallucination, flashback, I don't know what to call it- BERRISFORD
How about psychotic episode? ALAN
No, no, she doesn't fit the pattern-- BERRISFORD
Addictive personalities can be borderline. You know that-- ALAN
(patiently) She has no history of drug abuse-- BERRISFORD

There's other kinds of addictions. (standing, pensive) we see it in these fringe religious groups... these instant creeds with pseudo-Messianic delusions. You've heard how she talks about Unity House? Perhaps that's her drug. Perhaps she's going through a--withdrawal of sorts. Her memory lapses about Unity House are equally symptomatic... There's some violent turmoil under that pretty little facade. ALAN
(skeptical) You put her in the Borderline Group and she became one? BERRISFORD
No. CAMERA TIGHTENS ON HIM. BERRISFORD (CONT'D)
I believe she went into that coma a disturbed young lady. Fifteen years later... nothing has changed.
We can read the name on the locked security door (albeit backwards.) A SECURITY GUARD watches a basketball game on portable set.

This is not the room we saw when she was comatose, but a brighter, more residential arrangement. Cynthia sits on t bed, watches as Hettie counts out pills for her. Cynthia swallows them, hesitates at a red one. CYNTHIA
This one's new. HETTIE
It'll help you sleep. (explaining)

Sort of a post-elevator cocktail? Cynthia scowls, takes it. Hettie goes out. Cynthia lies down on the bed, stiff. Turns over once or twice. Sighing she picks up the TV remote, shakes her head at the myriad buttons. Finally she finds the right one, CLICKS IT. 39   TV - HER P.O.V. She's come in on the middle of a group therapy scene from BOB NEWHART SHOW. (NOTE: Or maybe THE SNAKE PIT or SHOCK
She watches until she realizes what it is, then CLICKS it off.
Hettie leans over the security guard's desk. The guard GROANS in frustration an the basketball game ends. HETTIE (extending her hand)
Pay up. Twenty bucks. Neither notices a DARK FIGURE passing by close to the CAM

Cynthia lies restlessly in her bed. She hears footsteps coming closer. They stop at her door. She looks over. There is a SHADOW moving in the crack under the door.   T doorknob TURNS. Cynthia sits up. CYNTHIA
Who's there? She reaches for the button to call the nurse, but then th door is OPEN, and the figure stands there silhouetted. FIGURE (whisper)

Cynthia? The figure comes forward. Cynthia backs off the other sid of the bed and turns on a light. It is Victor, the boy we remember from the opening scene. The years have been kind to him. He stands there, the dim light spilling on his Army field jacket and bell-bottomed jeans.
Cynthia?   It's me.   Victor. CYNTHIA (amazed)
Vic? Oh, my God-- She practically leaps across the room, hugs him with all strength. VICTOR
Look at you. (marveling)
Little Cyn. (impressed)
Not so little anymore. CYNTHIA
Vic, this is just... fantastic, it's the most incredible... (hesitating)
But... how can you be here?
Yeah.   It is after visiting hours--
I mean... they said that...      that everybody died.
(smiling) Do I look like a ghost to you?
(rapid-fire) How did you survive? How did you find me? Is anyone else--
Whoa, whoa. It's a long story... (looking around) Let me tell it somewhere else. I feel like I'm in, like, the Pentagon or something.
Cynthia grins, grabs a light jacket.
Then let's go AWOL.
Victor peeks out the door. An orderly passes, then disappears. Victor and Cynthia tiptoe out, sprint down th corridor to a stairwell marked "EXIT", and they are gone.
Victor takes her hand, and they run towards a battered VW van. We recognize it and its slogans.
Zeke!   You've still got Zeke!
She runs her hand along the dusty side lovingly, and then they hop inside.
Rusted, dated 1973.     The van DRIVES AWAY.
It's a tacky but cozy building, circa 1958. "Zeke" pulls rattling to a coughing halt. They get out, head up the steps.

They come in, turning on lights. It's a dingy couple of rooms, but lush with its variety of objects. Everything looks like it came from the Age of Aquarius: beanbag furniture, paper "Tiffany" shades on hanging lights, blacklight posters, hanging macrame planters. Cynthia loves the room and everything in it. But she is particularly drawn to a canvas on an easel in the far cor

It's of her, sitting serenely in a meadow, the Unity Hous perched prominently on a hill in the distance. (In the doorway, the bare-chested FIGURE of a man may--or may not barely visible.) Cynthia's clothes in the painting are th ones she wore in the opening scene. But her face is that of today's Cynthia.
VICTOR
I... did it by memory. I tried to imagine... what you'd... look like today. Guess I came pretty close. CYNTHIA
It's beautiful. More beautiful than I ever was. VICTOR (softly)
Then you need a new mirror. she smiles, flattered.    Suddenly a CAT jumps up on a cr VICTOR (CONT'D)
That's Chairman Meow. Cynthia picks him up.    Victor takes out a bottle of teq and two glasses.
You still haven't told me how you lived. I really can't remember anything about the... accident.
It wasn't an accident.
She stiffens.    His eyes are far away.

A lot of people back then, they hated Unity House. Hated Harris and his dreams... dreams of peace... of oneness. That hate fed negative energy into the cosmic vortex... Something bad was bound to happen. That hate was so strong... so envious of what we had...
He has SQUEEZED the shot glass in his hand so hard that i EXPLODES. Cynthia JUMPS, and that's when he notices it.
(very normal) Oh, fuck--
You've cut yourself--
She comes over, binds his hand with a dishcloth.     He h onto her.
I guess talking about the past can be a little dangerous.
He pours a shot into the remaining glass.
Let's drink to the present. (pause) To us.
He SIPS.   Passes the glass to her.
She hesitates...    smiles.   Drinks. There is a drop of blood in the glass.     She doesn't se
To us.
VICTOR (quietly)

To... Unity. He pulls her close. They KISS... she seems to malt in his grasp. The cat jumps down. Slowly they kiss and touch eac other. They stop and stare into each other's eyes. He moves his hand over her shoulders, neck, through her h She is completely his.

Half a dozen candles illuminate the room. Cynthia and Victor are making love. Not violent, but slow passionate, dreamlike. They are completely enjoying each other. The satisfaction seems spiritual. They stare into each other's eyes the entire time. They are lost. Gradually Victor's rhythm builds. As his momentum increas as the ecstasy nears, Cynthia accelerates too. Heaving, gasping, they are approaching a beautiful climax. But just when it seems Victor is on the verge, the very threshold, he stops and JUMPS violently out of bed.
Oh Jesus!
Victor? Victor paces around the room, practically bouncing off th walls. VICTOR
Oh, my God. I can't believe it. What a great idea...! Too amazing! Too amazing! CYNTHIA
Is something wrong?
VICTOR

Not wrong, Cynthia...right! The most right thing in the world! He goes to his closet and pulls out a shoe box. He holds with a coy expression, like a kid hiding a frog. Cynthia' annoyance with the break in mood fades in light of his exuberance. Their tone with each other remains loving, kidding. CYNTHIA
Are you going to tell me your little secret, or should I just got dressed? VICTOR
I'm sorry, Cyn, but I just got the most incredible idea. It's absolutely beautiful! Do you want to know what it is?
(exasperated)
Yes! He sits on the bad. VICTOR
I was just thinking about what we were doing here together... CYNTHIA
I should hope so... VICTOR
Wouldn't it be incredible if, right at the perfect moment right when we're coming, if we did it?
Did what? VICTOR
What we were meant to do, of course. CYNTHIA
(puzzled) ...meant to do...?
VICTOR
That sunset. That last night.      At Unity House. Remember? CYNTHIA
No...     No, Victor, I don't... VICTOR

(distant) They all got to go. You and me... we got left behind... while they went on. (chuckling) Guess that's why they say life ain't fair. Well... He opens the box.    Inside it are TWO PISTOLS. VICTOR (CONT'D)
--we can fix that. CYNTHIA
(stiffening) My God, Victor! Put those away-- He ignores her, checks the cylinder on the revolver, the on the automatic. VICTOR

This is so great! I mean, I've been living with all this shit, thinking about you, searching... going nowhere. And you, hell, you don't fit in with Ralph and Miriam, those other flakes... Berrisford and Goldman, they're a waste of time-- CYNTHIA
H-how do you know about them? I never-- He SLAMS the clip home, CLOSES the cylinder. VICTOR

Yeah. We had the answers, way back then. Unity. Unity, now and forever. Cynthia, this is our second chance! She shrinks away from him on the bed. He bounces closer l a kid at a pajama party, holds out one of the pistols.
VICTOR (CONT'D)
Okay, you do me, and I'll do you-- but wait until I say go! Hey, get rid of the sheet... Let me see that grown up body... He grins, puts the gun to her head and gets an top of her CYNTHIA
No, Vic. Please.       Please!   I don't want to do this! VICTOR
Yes, you do. You know you do. CYNTHIA
No! He's holding her down.   He's getting into it. VICTOR
Oh, Cynthia, it's so beautiful. CYNTHIA
God, God, no-- VICTOR
We're on the edge of space and time. He spreads her legs under the sheets. She's struggling against him, but it's no use. He's too strong. He's comin closer. VICTOR (CONT'D)
Oh, good... good... ummm... ummm... (continuing) Cynthia, it's happening. Put the gun to my head. CYNTHIA
Jesus, Vic, no! VICTOR
Yeah, oh yeah...     oh, YEAH-- A SHOT sounds.   She SCREAMS--
Cynthia BOLTS up out of bed.
No! The candles are out.    Victor isn't in the room. Cynthia, drenched with sweat, slowly catches her breath. looks around, confused.
Vic? She goes into the other room.
No Vic. It is dark except for a FIRE in the fireplace. Th flames REFLECT oddly on the slick surface of the oil pain of Unity House.

Vic? She checks in the kitchen. Nothing.       She looks back bedroom. The apartment is empty. She's just calming when--MEEOW! The CAT LEAPS out of nowhere, startling her, and then running out of sight. She swallows. Very nervous now, she sits on the couch and starts pulling on her jeans and shoes. The CAMERA MOVES AROUND her, revealing the entire apartment. We see EVERY ANGLE. It is completely quiet and still. The CAMERA SETTL at one ANGLE on Cynthia. A shadow behind her MOVES. VICTOR
Where are you going? Cynthia JUMPS from fright. CYNTHIA
Jesus, Vic. I thought you... left.
Me?    Leave you all alone? He pulls her into his arms.      She hesitates.
Vic?   Vic, are you... happy?
That... (kissing her) ...has to be.. (kissing again) ...the stupidest question I ever heard...
He keeps kissing, caressing.
I mean... with... life.   With... being alive.
He looks at her oddly.
What are you talking about?
(relaxing) Never mind... I had this... bizarre dream...
Welcome to reality.

He touches her soft face. He runs his hands down her neck They kiss again, she now completely without reservation. Their embrace is so all-encompassing that, when she opens eyes, it's only then that she SEES
She is kissing a BURNED AND SCARRED FACE WITH ONLY CLUMPS PUPPY BLACK MUSCLE HANGING ON THE BONE. It is Harris' fac the face we saw in the elevator. Cynthia GASPS, fumbles backwards off of the sofa.
What's the matter?
She looks back up at him.     He's Victor again, normal a
Cynthia?
She knocks over a tequila bottle. It's spilled all over t floor. She is speechless. He picks the bottle up.
VICTOR (CONT'D)
Why did you pull away?
I...    I think I'd better go.
Why? She's over by the door.    Victor comes and presses again so she can't get out. CYNTHIA
Please let me out. VICTOR
I don't understand...    What did I do? CYNTHIA
Nothing. It's not you, it...     it's me. I just want to go. VICTOR
You know, maybe you belong in that clinic, because this, this is crazy! We were having a good time-- (on her look)
I'm sorry. Look, what we were feeling... it was special. She softens-- VICTOR (CONT'D)
--it was Unity. (distantly)
Unity, Now and through Eternity... Cynthia, you cannot run... That does it.    Pale, she scrabbles at the doorknob, ope runs out.
You cannot run... You belong to us Forever--!
She runs out of the building, past "Zeke."      She looks
Victor is in the window waving, firelight dancing behind The reflection on the glass makes the painting on the wal look totally aflame.

head_text.subj: ETHEREAL SITAR MUSIC UP OVER THE FOLLOWING SEQUENCE

text: Cynthia has her thumb out as the cars whizz by.     One s
A sweaty-looking DRIVER eyes Cynthia.   She just looks of depressed and afraid.
She gets out of the car and goes in the main entrance.
She makes her way to her room looking tired, distraught.
She lies on her bed, exhausted, trying to sleep.     She She gets out of bad.

She's looking for an office. She goes in one marked Dr. Goldman. He looks up from his coffee, sees her ashen expression... pulls out a chair. Listens as the words tumble out. His expression changes... to skepticism... an then, as she breaks down SOBBING, to concern. He holds her... thinks... ...reaches for his car keys.
They are travelling along the highway.      Cynthia POINT turns onto another street.
They pull up in front, park.     Go inside. CAMERA LINGERS long enough for us to notice a puddle from OIL LEAK exactly where "Zeke" was parked. THE MUSIC FADES OUT.
The MANAGER, a fat woman in a muumuu, waddles ahead of th a huge keychain CLINKING with each of her steps. MANAGER
Apartment 2-B, right? Alan looks at Cynthia.
Right. MANAGER
2B or not 2B, that is the question. She chuckles at her own wit, arrives at the door.      Op
They step inside. The place is completely bare.       No furniture. Nothing. Cynthia is stunned.
B..but...     it... it's empty! MANAGER
Of course it is. I     don't show rented apartments.     Anyway, what you see is what you    get... one bedroom, gas range,    yadda yadda yadda. (MORE)
Supposed to be six months minimum, but you seem like nice kids, so if you want a month to month, we can work it out.
This... this is impossible... Alan, I was here... He was here-
Cynthia is staggering around the room, looking everywhere She stares long and hard at a DUST-FREE rectangle where t painting... ...might have been.
(to the manager) How long has this place been vacant?
'Bout six weeks. Couple a deadbeats... their damn kids tore the hell out of it, too--
Alan, I don't care what she says, this is it! Look, look-- (pointing) There's a double-door closet in there on the left.
Alan goes in.
Alan looks and sees the closet as she described it.
(as he comes back out) Well?
Cynthia, a double closet isn't exactly a positive I.D.--
What are you two talking about? You wanna rent, or what?
Cynthia looks around, suddenly points to a stain on the r triumphant.
There! There, look--that's where I spilled the tequila... (on her knees, desperate) See? See? It's still wet!
(apologetic) Hon, I think that's from the ceiling...
CAMERA TILTS UP. There is, indeed, a corresponding damp s directly above the one on the rug. As we WATCH a DRIP plo down.
...damn plumber was supposed to fix it last week. (smiling) So! We in business?
Wasserman SLAMS his hand down on the desk, furious. Cynth JUMPS, squeezes Alan's hand. Berrisford sits quietly, lea forward and picks up the pan holder Wasserman has displac

Twelve hours! You wait twelve hours to tell me about this? Am I supposed to be grateful for your civic-mindedness? I told you the Unity House case was still open-- (pointing at Cynthia) --and she's the only lead. You should have called me the minute you found out--
(calmly) Found out what? Lieutenant, if I called the police every time one of my patients experienced a fantasy or a delusion, you'd have to move in here--
CYNTHIA
(sharp, stepping forward) It was not a delusion! Victor Lunes was here-- BERRISFORD
The security guard didn't see anyone-- CYNTHIA
Then the security guard needs glasses! Alan, tell them-- ALAN
(on the spot) The apartment did match her general description-- WASSERMAN
--a one bedroom flat with a beige rug... that's rather... generic. CYNTHIA
--Victor isn't generic-- WASSERMAN
Victor is dead! Dead for fifteen years-- CYNTHIA
--you've seen his body? WASSERMAN
--it was burned beyond recognition-- but there was I.D.-- CYNTHIA
I knew it--I knew it- ALAN
Cynthia. Look... we've all done it... tumbled out of bed positive that we've just lived something that was only a dream-- CYNTHIA
(firmly) Damn it, it wasn't a dream--I was out there--
WASSERMAN

No one's denying you flow the coop, Miss Weston... You wanna prove the rest? Lemme get a policewoman to stand by while a gynecologist checks out your plumbing. We'll see soon enough if your ghost left a calling card-- Cynthia hauls off and gives Wasserman a tremendous SLAP. CYNTHIA
You bastard. She goes to the door, looks at the doctors. CYNTHIA (CONT'D)
You... (searching) --experts! She goes out, SLAMS the door.    Wasserman rubs his jaw, his mouth. BERRISFORD

Wonderful! Wonderful! I've been waiting and waiting for her to finally show real anger--real emotion! This could be a breakthrough! (sincere) Thank you, Lieutenant. Wasserman holds a filling in his fingertips. WASSERMAN
Hey.   Anytime.
CAMERA PANS past a row of PILLOWS. We WIDEN, see that eac member of the group has a big pillow in front of them. ALAN
Okay. First off, we're all going to feel a little silly and maybe look a little silly...
(a la Groucho) Especially in that shirt you're wearing, Goldman...
She sits, looking very distracted. As Alan continues speaking, he occasionally looks at her, but--to her relie deliberately doesn't single her out.
(amused, but pushing on) --but this technique works, and we're going to release some of our hidden aggression. Who's going to go first? Lana?
(pause) How many helpless goose had to die to fill those stupid pillows?
(as everyone groans) None, Lana. They're polyester. Ed? Want to start?
Nah. Let's talk about the geese again. Nice fat ones, with all the trimmings--
All right, how about if we all start together and eliminate the wimp factor. Come on.
He starts POUNDING his pillow with a steady beat. Gradual self-consciously, the others JOIN in except for Cynthia.
(standing, walking around the circle) Okay. What are we feeling?
(as she pounds) We used to do something like this in the royal palace in Atlantis. But we used bags of dried kelp.
Your brain is a bag of dried kelp--
(chiding)
Ralph. Miriam?
(pounding)
I'm pretending this is my first husband... No, maybe my third... (grinning)
Can I have a baseball bat?
Please, people, let's work at being serious. He moves behind Cynthia, who's still unmoving.   Leans cl whispers.
I know you had a rough night.   But you have to participate. She sighs, starts to pound the pillow. At first she's ver distracted, but then she gets into an unconscious rhythm.
All of them are finally and legitimately exorcising perso demons.

Okay, that's better. Now let's hear some emotion. Let it out. yell! Scream! Miriam gives a very theatrical scream. There's some laughter, but others try, too. Gilda begins to give littl angry yelps. Ralph is really punching some ancient enemy. Connie does a respectable if modest SCREAM. Ed SNARLS wit more anger than we'd expect.
begins hitting the pillow with growing strength. Her eyes are far away. She begins to BREATHE HEAVILY. CAMERA TIGHTENS ON HER. She closes her eyes. When she opens them she REACTS TO--

The scene in exactly like the first time we saw this room with one difference: the hospital Group Therapy crowd sit the room. They are oblivious to the change around them. N their pounding gradually UNIFIES, becomes a background vo like DRUMMING. Cynthia is speechless. She looks at then in amazement, bu none of them notice her. Suddenly she sees
He's across from her, SMILING.    Again, he sleeks back h hair in that amber liquid.
You failed me, Cynthia...   You failed all of us... Harris holds a wooden match. With it he presses back a fingernail. It snaps off and bleeds. Harris watches Cynthia.
We were supposed to be together... in this world... and in the next... CAMERA WIDENS to take in the cistern of liquid.    We SEE dripping wet Unity members.

It was going to be perfect, all of us taking the same journey... You shouldn't have run. You made us wait for you while you slept... all those years. He presses back another nail SNAP. CAMERA WIDENS FURTHER. Now we see something we didn't see before: a dozen or so PLASTIC JERRY CANS marked "GASOLINE--DANGER--PLAMMABLE."
The waiting time is over, my lovechild. It's time for you to join us. In Unity... Another.   SNAP.   Hands and faces everywhere are soaked. DRIP.
In death.    You know you want it.
SNAP.   Drip.

Her throat muscles constrict, but she can't speak. She lo over at Alan, who seems not to see any of this. Now, eyes widening in horror, Cynthia LOOKS DOWN and sees a POOL OF GASOLINE SPREADING TOWARDS HER. It washes against the pillow, her knees.
You know we're your family...
SNAP.   Drip.
...You have no choice...
He takes the match and strikes it through the pile of nai The nails scatter.
...Come to us, Cynthia. It's time to die. Don't lot another take your place. Come to us... now.
The match is lit.    He throws it off.
It FALLS through the air. Lands on the soaked carpet.   A EXPLOSION of flames. They RUSH TOWARDS CYNTHIA--
NOOOOOOOOO--!
It is a blood-curdling and heart-stopping a scream as eve heard. There is a FLASH of light.
Cynthia's SCREAM trails off as she THROWS herself back fr the pillow. The Unity House Members and Harris are all gone. The group therapy people all turn to her in amazement.
Open mouthed, she DROPS the match she's holding to light cigarette. It SIZZLES on the rug. Alan STOMPS it out, rushes over to Cynthia, who SAGS in his arms,

Cynthia sits in a crumpled sprawl in Alan's office. The r is decorated in comforting tones, with Sierra Club poster and outdoors-y souvenirs. The late afternoon sun steams i through the partially closed blinds. Alan sits beside Cynthia on the couch, concerned.   Berri sucks on his pipe, makes notes. Wasserman, rocking on the legs of his chair, jots in his little notebook.
(softly, tense)

...They... they sang songs as they stacked up the white containers... they were... happy. Because it was going to be their break with the world... a world that didn't understand them. I don't remember if they took a vote or if Harris just... decided. But they all agreed. They were... happy... smiling... laughing... crying from happiness as he drenched them in the gasoline...
(under his breath)
--Jesus--
CYNTHIA

Somehow, I... I knew it was wrong... I ran... When he threw the match, I was at the other end of the hallway... There was a flash... and a... like a wind, or the hand of God--picked me up, threw me... The ceiling fell in... When I opened my eyes... (she looks up) I was here. Hettie appears in the doorway, tray in hand, raises her eyebrows inquisitively at Alan. Alan nods immediately: He yes. Hettie comes in, gives Cynthia her medication. Wasserman closes his book, looks thoughtful. ALAN
(to Wasserman) If that's what happened, why didn't you find any evidence of arson? WASSERMAN

The plastic jerry cans would've burned up before anything else... We knew there'd been an explosion... We just didn't know how or why. Berrisford stands, approaches Wasserman as the police off closes his book, moves to the doorway. BERRISFORD
Well. You must be pleased. Closing a case after... what is it, twelve years? WASSERMAN
Who says it's closed? The medical people look at him.      Cynthia's thoughts a elsewhere. ALAN
What's that supposed to mean? WASSERMAN
When the fairy princess here woke up, she said she didn't remember anything about 32 deaths. Now she remembers they committed suicide... (MORE)
but she, of course, was innocent. Who knows what she'll remember tomorrow? Running for help... or pouring gasoline on the fire? He goes out. HETTIE
That man's a candidate for shock therapy... with a car battery right to the cojones. CYNTHIA
No... he's right.     I am guilty. They look at her, startled. CYNTHIA (CONT'D)
I'm guilty of lying... to Unity House. I promised to be part of it... Forever. They expected me to keep my word. (pause)
They still do. She stands, goes out. Alan and Hettie look worried. Berrisford looks... unsurprised. He turns to Alan. BERRISFORD
Well, Alan. Still think she doesn't belong in the group? Alan just looks at him.
Cynthia, in her bathrobe, wanders out of the shower in between the dark, steamy rows of lockers. She passes Lana and Miriam. Miriam is dressing, and Lana is putting on a swimsuit. MIRIAM
Nothing like a hot shower, huh? Cynthia doesn't hear or see them. She settles on the far of the bench. She sits there blankly. Lana nears, with great trepidation.
Cynthia?   Cynthia?   Are you okay?
Cynthia looks up. CYNTHIA
What? LANA
Are you all right?    After that session today, I-- CYNTHIA
I'm fine. Cynthia starts to dress, ignoring Lana.         Lana stan for a moment, very awkwardly. LANA
I think... you're a decent person... not a... mean spirited witch like some people... She thrown a look at Miriam, who just smiles pleasantly. LANA (CONT'D)
--and, well, if you need a friend here... CYNTHIA
(distant tone) All my friends are dead. Rattled, Lana backs off, on the verge of tears, rushing p Miriam, who has observed all this. MIRIAM
Lana, wait a minute, she didn't mean it--shit. Miriam closes her locker and comes over to Cynthia. MIRIAM (CONT'D)
I know Lana's a mealy-mouthed little prude, but she means well. I probably pull her chain too much... She's reaching out, like all of us. Try and help her. CYNTHIA
I can't even help myself. Miriam looks at her, puzzled, then exits the locker room, heading back to the ward.
Beyond the lockers, through a doorway, we see Lana loweri herself into the pool. Blue ripples line the wall beyond.
(echo affect)
Be cleansed! The SOUND of the VOICES unnerves Cynthia.     She presses hands against her forehand in pain. We are TIGHT ON Cynthia.    We hear SPLASHING.
Cleanse the heart of your mind. A bright white light melts across Cynthia's face.     She up. Something draws her forward.
She begins walking, passing behind CLOTHES RACKS and LOCK Then, somehow, the SHADOWS of these things become the SHA of TREES, and then Cynthia is

which leads down to a POND. Twenty or so PEOPLE are gathe at the edge of the water. We see the Unity House in the distance. Cynthia moves behind a tree to watch. Harris stands waist deep in the pond. The Unity House Members all sit or stan on the shore. Harris holds his hands out in a gesture. A girl comes forward through the group out into the water. is Cynthia, the younger Cynthia, with long hair in a brai She smiles at Harris as she nears him. He clutches her hands. Behind the tree, Cynthia watches "herself," absorb Harris looks into Cynthia's eyes.    He touches her face.
Cynthia.     You are part of the whole. He grabs her by the back of the head and plunges her violently under water.
Cleanse the heart of the mind! He yanks her up.   She smiles exultantly.    He dunks her down.
Cleanse the soul of the self! He yanks her up again, but it's not Cynthia. It's LANA. Before she can catch her breath, she's plunged back down.
She's yanked up, but this time she's not in the pond, she in that gasoline-filled cistern!
Cleanse the spirit of the body! He holds her under. She starts to move her arms around to grab hold of something to pull herself up, but Harris is strong. She flails around desperately.
Alarmed, she moves forward--
(distant)
Cleanse the spirit. Lana's gasping, inhaling water, turning blue.    Harris i possessed.
Cleanse. Her movements slow.   Her eyes close.   She is completely still.
He looks directly at Cynthia.
I warned you, Cynthia. I warned you someone else would take your place.
His HAND withdraws from Lana. Her eyes OPEN. No life ther

head_text.subj: SHE FLOATS UPWARDS. THE CAMERA BREAKS THE SURFACE OF THE

text: We're in the clinic's swimming pool! On the edge of the pool, Cynthia SCREAMS, drops to her knees in horror.
The clinic CUSTODIAN and some staff run into the room.
Someone wades out to Lana's body, drags it to the concret deck, tries futilely to pump life back into it. Across the pool, Cynthia flails at the people trying to h her.

TIGHT on Cynthia's arm as a clear liquid is injected into vein. We WIDEN, see Berrisford has injected her. Alan watches, concerned. Cynthia flails on the bed, already reacting to the sedati qualities of the drug.

--He killed her--he killed her because I broke my word... He said he'd take someone else, and he did... She wanted my help... my friendship... That's why... he took her... She's out cold. Behind the doctors, in the doorway, the other clinic patients press close, curious. Hettie pushes them out and down the hallway.
Move it, people, this ain't a sideshow... Get back to your rooms... Alan looks down at Cynthia with genuine concern.    But Berrisford eyes her totally clinically.
(thinking aloud)
Fascinating.

She's a textbook specimen from a collective environment, an immersion philosophy, run by an extremely manipulative figurehead with Messianic delusions. Unity House at its apex must have been a classic matrix of belief impression overlaid on collectivity-- (exciting himself) That would indicate she's symptomatic of a hypothetical Borderline Personality syndrome among cult followers, all externalizing their anxiety! (turning) What do you think?
Alan looks at him disbelievingly.
(exploding) I think she's fucking freaked out about Lana!
(a shrug) Possible.
The patients file past the nurse's station, taking their from Hettie. They look unsettled.
(aside to Ralph) Did you see the swimming pool this morning? The cops are all over it... Fingerprints, photographs...
Next they'll send in the fucking coast guard. Lot of good it'll do Lana.
HE SMASHES his fist on the counter, denting it.    Hettie at him.
Ralph, we're gonna start billing you for these outbursts.
Ralph just crumples his medication cup and throws it towa her. She glares at him, doesn't say anything.
Cynthia and the other women from the group sit in a waiti area. Connie sits in a sunbeam, looking ethereal. Gilda i nearby, unmoving... tear stains on her cheeks.
Drowning isn't so bad... I remember when I died in Atlantis... It was like failing asleep. You know what's bad? Burning. When I was in the great Fire of London, well, let me tell you--
Hearing this, Cynthia chokes back a sob, jumps up and lea the room. Miriam whirls on Connie.
Connie, I don't know about your previous lives, but in this one, you're a shithead.
She follows Cynthia.
Cynthia is on the bad, crying. Miriam comes in, sits besi her... Cynthia jumps at the weight on the bad, calms when she sees who it is.
Honey, you can't blame yourself. Lana was an unhappy girl. Sometimes unhappy girls do foolish things.
She didn't kill herself.
Cynthia sits up.
It was Harris.
Harris?
CYNTHIA
From Unity House. He comes to me, Miriam. He talks to me. He reminds me that I was supposed to go with them that night-- MIRIAM
Go with them-- CYNTHIA

Through the fire. To the next world. They waited while I was in a coma... He told me that if I didn't join him, he would take someone also... and he did it, Miriam, he did it! Miriam gets up, her face a mixture of sympathy... sympath and something else. She lights a cigarette. Involuntarily Cynthia FLINCHES at the spark. CYNTHIA (CONT'D)
You...   you don't believe me, do you? MIRIAM

I believe that you believe it. And I also believe that shooting you up every time you get the heebie- jeebies ain't gonna do shit for your real problems. We gotta get you out of here--get you to some nice place at the beach or the mountains where you can fight your demons in your own way. Right? CYNTHIA
But I don't know anyone.   I don't have any money. MIRIAM
You know me. CYNTHIA
(skeptical) And you have money, right?

Look. Despite popular opinion to the contrary, I have not always been the career borderline psychotic neurotic that I am today. Up until a coupla years ago I was a writer, a reporter, a damn good one too... Hell, I really kicked some ass with that Selectric... She seems lost in thought for a moment. Unconsciously, sh scratches her wrist... a wrist where we notice for the fi time a PURPLE SCAR across the veins.
(turning)
I was on the staff of a magazine... Well, some people called it a rag, but it was home: ME! Magazine. You heard of it?
(shaking her head, diplomatic)
I was in a coma.

Oh, right. Well, when they took me off to the funny farm, Saul--he's the editor--he said I was always welcome back. Maybe this is the time. See, if I can go to him, tell him your story, I could get a big advance... I'd share it with you, and we'd be set! I mean, girl, your story has everything... death, hospitalization, weird rituals, maybe a little romance-- I've seen all those longing glances between you and Goldman-
What--!
--and now with poor Lana we got a little mystery. Hell, you're not an article, you're a goddamned mini- series!
I...   I don't know... MIRIAM

Cynthia, let me be honest. This is a great story, and it means a second chance for me, so, okay, there's some self interest here. But I really think you need to tell people about Unity House... about the way decent ideas and dreams got twisted into something sick and poisonous. You owe it to the world. You owe it to yourself. It's your life, and you have to ask yourself how you want to live it... (sharper)
--if you want to live it. Cynthia turns, mind made up. CYNTHIA
Let's do it.
Cynthia walks along with Miriam towards the banks of elevators. MIRIAM
I think I know a way to make a phone call. We'll have you out of here tonight. Miriam suddenly stops, almost paralyzed with anxiety.
Cynthia.    This is the right thing to do. CYNTHIA
Of course it is.
Uh oh.     Mum's the word. Alan is coming down the hallway towards them.   They move towards the elevator.
ALAN
(nodding) Ladies. Good to see you socializing, Cynthia.
Yes. (to Miriam) See you later. And...     thanks.
Thank you. Miriam then gets into the elevator.         The doors rem Alan turns to Cynthia. ALAN
How are you feeling?
Fine.

Good. He heads off in the opposite direction. Cynthia watches h She turns back towards Miriam. Miriam is alone in the elevator except for one other person. Miriam smiles and waves. Cynthia smiles and waves. From behind Miriam, Harris, all burned and puffy, smiles waves. The elevator doors close.
No! Alan whirls around.       Cynthia rushes to the elevator. CYNTHIA (CONT'D)
Miriam!    Stop! She bangs on the buttons. She pounds on the doors. in the corridor turns to look.
Cynthia?
He starts to approach.   She runs to a stairwell.
Cynthia sprints down a flight.    She goes out onto
Cynthia runs to the elevator and pounds on the button, bu the elevator car has already passed. CYNTHIA (yelling into the door)
Miriam, get out! She races back to
She flies down the steps.    We can hear ALAN tailing her
Cynthia! She swings around a turn into a flight and trips.     Sud she's ROLLING DOWN A
She SLAMS into a tree.   We see the Unity House in the distance.
Cynthia! ANOTHER VOICE
She's trying to get away! There are PEOPLE pounding through the brush all around he She gets up and runs along the path into the forest. VOICE
Cynthia! We want you to stay with us! You mustn't be afraid! She is in total panic, running blindly.
Please, no.

Branches thrash her face. She can barely see where she is going, but she comes to a halt when she reaches a dark precipice, a cliff which seemingly has no bottom--just bl as night. The people are getting nearer.
She's over here.
We see someone nearing through the brush.
No pain, Cynthia. There's no pain. Come with us. Share with us. Take my hand.
Cynthia looks down the cliff.
Take my hand.
Cynthia backs away. She starts lowering herself down, try to get footing. Some rocks slide out.
Cynthia, take my hand.
The Orderly rushes to her, but she wavers dizzily and FAL down the half-flight. She's dazed, but she becomes alert when she sees the orderly approaching. She picks herself and runs.

She gets to the elevator. The door is just closing, but i opens again against a purse--Miriam's purse. The elevator empty. Cynthia whips around looking for her. Orderlies an nurses are moving towards her. At the opposite and of the hallway, a window is broken. Cynthia runs to it. There is a WOMAN'S SCREAM from the street below. PEOPLE YELLING. Cynthia looks out and down. We know what she sees.    She covers her face.
An orderly takes hold of her. She is docile now, almost weak. Alan runs up. He looks out the window. So does a Nurse.
Jesus.
The nurse crosses herself.    Cynthia is escorted away am confusion.

The CAMERA IS MOVING FORWARD, TOWARDS the window. It seemingly goes OUT THROUGH THE WINDOW. The FRAME is filled with bright blue sky. Silence, except for a slight BREEZE. Someone is falling through the sky.       It is MIRIAM. We see her CLOSER, flowing down, the wind rushing up roun her. She is happy.
Cynthia, it's really quite beautiful.
The ground comes rushing up and we SLAM into it. BLACK.
It's not a session.    It's a wake.   Cynthia sits, face shadow.
They want us all now. They want us with them. Whether we like it or not, we're going,
Cynthia, we're all upset by what's happened. But let's not get--
CYNTHIA
Harris promised us eternal bliss on the other side when we're all together. CONNIE
Eternal bliss.... RALPH
Eternal bullshit--! CYNTHIA
Miriam was going to write a story about me. He killed her because she was going to help me got out of here. ALAN
Cynthia, please... CYNTHIA

You're not listening to me! He wants us all to die! He wants you all with them, and it's because of me! (sobbing) It's all because of me... Berrisford addresses a pack of about thirty REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS and CAMERAMEN. FIRST REPORTER
Dr. Berrisford, what would you call two suicides on your promises so close together? BERRISFORD
I'd call it a tragic coincidence. Unfortunately, Borderline Personality Disorder is indicative of a pre-existing disposition towards suicidal tendencies. SECOND REPORTER
What about the commune girl? Has she confirmed that the fire was some sort of mass suicide? BERRISFORD
As that is a police matter, I am not at liberty to comment on it.
Speaking of the police, doctor, isn't it true that they suspect that the recent deaths may not have been suicides at all?
That's completely absurd.   Where do you get this nonsense?
(a smug smile)
From Lieutenant Wasserman. He confirmed to me that he's assigning some of his officers to the hospital grounds until further notice. Pandemonium as the other reporters seize this information
(rapid fire)
Doctor Berrisford, are you cooperating with the police? Dr. Berrisford, do your patients have a history of violence?
Ah... I have work to do.    No further questions. And--flustered for once--he leaves the room.
It is raining.   Cynthia sits in bed, in the dark. We see the CHARRED AND BURNED HARRIS sitting across the r in a shadow. Cynthia looks over at him.
You're in pain, Cynthia. He reaches up to his face, and peels off some skin.    It CRACKLES and oozes. He peels off more.
Your pain is my pain. We share it all, because we have our love.
Our love will never die. Don't make me take another of your friends. Keep your promise, lovechild. Join me.

She stands, fumbles for the switch, knocks over a glass, turns on the light. He is gone. As she stands there in shock, a HAND touches shoulder, spins her around. She GASPS-- It's Alan, who's just opened the door.        He looks at worried.
I didn't want you to be alone.
She sways, dizzy, sags in his arms.
Looks like I was right.
Connie is sitting on her bad. She takes her pills from Hettie dutifully. Ed comes in.
What are you doing here?
You know me at feeding time.

He takes his meds from her, smiling. CHEWS THEM loudly an sloppily until she grimaces and goes out. Then, the minute the door closes, Ed and Connie are in ea other's arms. They kiss like characters in a Harlequin Romance.
(coming up for air) Why didn't you tell me before that you were a Prince of Ancient Atlantis?
It slipped my mind ...    your Highness.
She kisses him passionately again.    He breaks the clinc pulls her towards the door.
They'll have bed check soon.   I know a better place.
Alan site on the counter across from Cynthia's bed.    He with the hinged mirror on the wall.
I don't know if you want to hear this or not, and frankly, I don't care.
As he toys with the mirror, we see a CANTED REFLECTION of first Cynthia and then the hallway. A nurse passes by.
As she listens.
You are no more responsible for those deaths twelve hours ago than you are for the ones twelve years ago.
Something catches her eye.
Connie and Ed walk by.

Thinking otherwise is putting you in a self-replicating spiral of depression. And that puts me in a bind... What do I do, write more prescriptions? You need to face reality, not get medicated out of it...
Cynthia GASPS.    HARRIS HAS APPEARED IN THE MIRROR, foll Ed and Connie.
Cynthia jumps up, heads for the door.    Alan catches her the wrist,
Damn it, Cynthia, you can't run away from this--
It's Harris--he's going to do something to Connie--to Ed--!
Alan SLAPS her.    She pales... tries to hit him back.
Good! Get mad--get angry--but not at me--at these fantasies--!
She stands on rocky feet, unsure...
Connie and Ed come to a door marked "Utility." Ed looks around cautiously and opens the door, relieved that it's still unlocked.
Once inside the small space, he kisses Connie. He pulls o a pint flask of schnapps from his bathrobe pocket. He giv her a swig.
(wistful) Nectar from the grapes of Atlantis!
No fooling you.
He leads her back to a door that's labeled "DANGER: Authorized Personnel Only." The lock is busted open. in.

There are metal grating steps leading up to a platform th sits adjacent to a huge spinning turbine, its six-foot bl WHIRRING at top speed. Air ducts lead in and out of the space. Connie is uplifted, frightened, exhilarated. Their clothe and hair are blown around. They ascend the platform, and across from each other. They each take a swig. They kiss softly, spiritually.
I'm so happy.
The door to the utility room CLOSES.   It LOCKS.

Connie and Ed stare into each other's eyes.   They are lo The CAMERA MOVES IN AND OUT between and around them, exploring the depth of their absorption. The CAMERA MOVES TOWARDS the huge spinning turbine. Its SOUND builds to a tremendous ROAR. We see Connie and Ed through the door into the turbine ro The door is pulled closed by someone or something. The kn locks.
Cynthia keeps looking at the door, worried.

Miriam and Lana were both deeply disturbed women. Miriam tried to kill herself before. Lana was obsessed with the morbid... You heard her in the sessions. You can't twist what they did into something other than what it was. Just then, all the lights go OUT.
Now what?
In the darkness, he stumbles towards the light, flicks it Nothing. The door OPENS. In the dim light of the hallway emergency lamps, we SEE Cynthia go out.
Damn it, Cynthia, come back--!
Trying to follow, he COLLIDES With some furniture.
Shit--!
Darkness and confusion. Cynthia passes by the CAMERA. A moment later Alan comes by, looking for her. Other patien come out and wonder. Flashlights. A NURSE streams by.
It's just overloaded circuits. Everyone, please go back into your room.
CAMERA ADJUSTS to show an elderly, skeletal custodian, ED on the phone.
The turbine room upstairs? All right. (he hangs up) We'll set it straight in a minute. Somethin's caught in the turbine.
Hurry.
Edgar comes up to the utility door, but it won't budge.
Goddammit.
He walks off.

This is a low passageway between floors. Edgar has to sto under the ducts and pipes. He comes to a small hatchway i the coiling above him marked "CAUTION: Turbine." There is a latch which has to be pulled to release the hatchway. Edgar pulls. It's stuck. He yanks with his frai body. The latch barely moves. A TRICKLE OF BLOOD streams out at the edge, but Edgar doe see it. Edgar yanks and pulls with all his might, groaning and heaving. Finally he stops in frustration. He sits an a duct, resting. Just then the latch undoes itself. The hatchway slams ope Edgar is showered with red lumpy fluid. He is coated with it.
What the hell?
Edgar looks down. In the pool of red is a woman's shoe. Puzzled, he bends down, picks it up. Something FALLS OUT IT.
It is a SEVERED HUMAN FOOT.
as he reacts in shock, the spinning turbine begins to SPLATTER DROPS OF BLOOD on him.
Cynthia comes towards us.       Alan, further down the ha her.
Cynthia--!
Cynthia turns, reacts...       and then reacts to--
Cynthia.   Cynthia.
Connie?
She goes into another corridor. Alan hurries to catch up, but then has to help a nurse with a frightened OLDER WOMA
Cynthia.
Cynthia moves down the hall a bit.       She looks up at coiling.
Cynthia, we're up here!
Down the hall further, another vent.
Come with us, Cynthia!
You must join us, Cynthia!
Cynthia follows the voices. She is underneath another lar vent with a fan spinning inside. Everyone in the hall ignores her.
Cynthia, you must reach out and embrace our love for you... You must reach out to me...
We see Harris now, behind the fan, in brief flashes of li burnt then normal, gazing down at Cynthia. He reaches towards her.
Where are Connie and Ed?
His fingers ARE SLICED OFF BY THE FAN.       He takes no
They're with us now.
We hear SPLASHING. Cynthia looks over. Gallons of blood a solid matter pour out of the ceiling vents all down the h
Where are they? (she is frantic)

Where are Connie and Ed?   Where are they? Alan wonders at the pouring red, then he hears Cynthia screaming. He runs down the hall to stop her. The patients and nurses watch the blood pour in horror. Cynthia is getting more and more hysterical.
Where are Connie and Ed? Alan corners her.
It's all right--it's all right-- Suddenly, out of nowhere, a BL00D-COVERED BODY careens in them, driving them apart!
It's Edgar, covered with blood, in a total state of shock
--horrible--sweet Jesus--help me-- Alan struggles to restrain him.   Nurses run to help.
Huddles on the floor in a position not unlike the one fro her coma. She SOBS uncontrollably.
Alan and an orderly escort Cynthia to her room. Alan come out, watches Edgar pass by in a wheelchair, raving. Ralph and Gilda come up to Alan.
What the fuck is going on?
It's Ed and Connie.    They're dead, aren't they?
Alan looks at her.       How did the grapevine got it to fast?
Yes. We're not sure what happened... There was evidence that they were drinking... They fell into... the main turbine.
Fuck... Look, Ed drank before. Lots of times. Didn't know that, did you? But he didn't usually decide to jump into a mix master, man!
Ralph, as for your own safety, you are being given the most amount of protection possible.
The police are powerless.    Ask Cynthia. She knows. (softly) Harris wants us all.
